content: The Act is titled the "American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act Amendments." It defines the term "Commission" as the Indian Trust Reform Commission. It also mentions the Office of Special Trustee for American Indians and the Indian Trust Reform Commission. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 is amended to establish the Indian Trust Fund Reform Commission and set a 2-year term for the Special Trustee. The Indian Trust Fund Reform Commission is composed of members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of the Interior, ensuring fair representation. The Indian Trust Fund Reform Commission ensures fair representation of different interests, including Indian tribes and individual account holders. Members must have relevant experience in trust assets, tribal government, or be serving on the advisory board. The Indian Trust Fund Reform Commission appoints members with expertise in trust assets or tribal government. The advisory board members can also serve on the Commission. The chairperson is selected by consensus among the Secretary of the Interior, Speaker of the House, and Senate Majority Leader. Initial appointments are made for the Commission members. The Commission members are appointed within 60 days of enactment, serve for life, and vacancies are filled within 60 days. The Commission holds its first meeting within 30 days of a majority appointment, and meetings are called by the Chairman with a majority quorum required. The Commission, chaired by the Chairman, requires a majority for a quorum to hold hearings. It is tasked with duties specified in section 303(a) and has the power to conduct hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions under the Act. The Commission may use the United States mails, accept gifts, and compensate members who are not federal employees. The Commission members are entitled to daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code, while engaged in Commission duties. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission do not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members at rates authorized for agency employees. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws, with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Board without reimbursement, and the Chairman can procure temporary services. The Chairman can procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 4. REINVENTION STRATEGY. Section 303 of the American Indian Trust Fund Management Act of 1994 is amended to require the Commission to prepare a recommended reinvention strategy for trust management in consultation with Indian tribes and organizations. The Commission is responsible for developing a reinvention strategy for trust management in consultation with Indian tribes and organizations. Within 90 days, they must meet to consider and adopt the strategy for recommendation. The Commission must develop a reinvention strategy for trust management in consultation with Indian tribes and organizations. They will modify the strategy if approved by a majority vote and submit it for recommendation to specified individuals and entities.
